QuestionStem: These photos show three different objects as they appear when observed through a microscope. As you read the descriptions, think about how cells relate to each object.

images.caption: A paramecium is an organism made up of a single cell. Tiny hairlike structures, called cilia, surround the cell. The cilia beat back and forth, allowing the paramecium to move through the water where it lives.
images.altText: The magnified image shows the one cell that makes up a paramecium. The cell is an oval, and some structures inside the cell are visible.

images.caption: This photo shows thousands of cells that make up a shrimp’s eye. Shrimp are able to detect very fast motion because of the arrangement of specialized cells in their eyes.
images.altText: The magnified image shows a cross section of a shrimp's eye. Cells of different shapes, sizes, and colors are arranged in rings.

images.caption: The tip of this pencil is made of graphite, which is a form of carbon, mixed with clay. This mixture of materials leaves a gray mark on paper, which is easily erased.
images.altText: In this magnified image, we see a pencil point. The lead appears smooth and solid grey.
